title: How did Russian veterans of the Soviet-Afghan War feel towards their former comrades who had defected to the Mujahideen or were lost or captured and would become integrated into the Afghan society? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my opinion, this topic is long in the past. Every year on TV show amateur films of veterans about meetings with former enemies from Afghanistan, about the life of former Soviet soldiers. It seems that they have forgiven each other long ago.  25 лет спустя ветеран-"афганец" подружился с бывшими врагами - here is the story of Valery and Usmani (use a translator). Once they fought against each other, then they fought together, then the war ended for Valery, but continued for Usmani (with the Americans). Now they are friends. Once Valery and his Soviet soldiers saved local residents from death. They have not forgotten about it. In gratitude, they erected a monument for shuravi high in the mountains. This is the only monument to Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan.  This is Nikolai. He was held captive by the Afghans for a year, converted to Islam and was given a new name, Ismatullah. In the USSR, he was considered a traitor. He didn't want to go to jail and upset his relatives in Russia. Therefore, he remained in Afghanistan and served with Ahmad Shah Massoud. Thanks to Masud's order, Nikolai was not shot, so he felt grateful to the leader of the Mujahideen. Nikolai came to Russia with his family, but his mother had already died, so he returned back to Afghanistan. - Свои среди чужих. Как советские солдаты остались жить в афганском плену  Sergei has the most touching story. He was bullied by his commanders, and fled from the unit. He wanted to find superior commanders and ask for their help and protection. But they managed to accuse him of a crime - the commanders, who offended him, accused him of stealing army property and selling it to the Mujahideen. Sergei did not have time to reach the higher commanders, he was captured. He was held captive for twenty days, but then released. He was offered to stay or leave at his choice. Sergei understood that this was a hoax. He will definitely be shot if he chooses to go to the Soviet troops. He wanted to live, and he chose to stay. Sergey lived with the Afghans for a year. During this time, he converted to Islam and received a new name Nurmamad. Then he married a local girl. Sergei assures that he did not have time to start fighting: when he was captured, he was still a young soldier and had just arrived in Afghanistan, and did not have time to take part in any battle. He also did not have a chance to fight with the Afghans, the Mujahideen did not trust him and did not take him with them. The only thing he did was fix their weapons. Then they married him and sent him to live in the village. All his life he worked in his profession, which he received in the USSR - he is an electrician. He worked at a local hydroelectric power station, and moonlighted at a quarry. Свои среди чужих. Как советские солдаты остались жить в афганском плену It should be noted that the fate of only 6 former Soviet soldiers who went to the Afghans is well known. Two of them later returned to Russia and were amnestied. The four continue to live in Afghanistan. The fate of the rest of the missing soldiers is unknown. Journalists, diplomats, military personnel and their relatives continue to search for them.

There were total 417 MIA in Afghan conflict, of them 287 remained unaccounted by 1989, the rest liberated or their bodies found and identified. Defections weren’t that much an issue. Maybe two dozen defected overall largely belonging to two groups. One group were men under investigation for different crimes, mostly the theft of military property, others hoping to escape to the West through Pakistan. There was even one officer among them - a head of intelligence of one of regiments lt. colonel Nikolai Zajac. He shot two officers of Afghan KHAD suspected in cooperation with Mujahideen, but then decided to defect to avoid court martial, stolen the armored vehicle in process. The terrorists realized that if they’d keep him there would be harsh repercussions, killed him and handed the body to authorities. It was a rather scandalous event attracting some publicity but I believe most other defections resulted in similar outcome with very rare exceptions. At least two people known to actually make it to the West and later contacted their families from US. The attitude to them was of course negative, but legally they were amnested after the war. One of such people is Nikolai Bystrov - a personal bodyguard of Akhmadshakh Masoud.  At first he wasn’t a willing defector but captured unconscious in an ambush. They were impressed by his bravery and later managed to coerce him into cooperation. He indeed used amnesty and repatriated back home with his Afghan wife and kids, currently living in Ust-Labynsk.

Never discussed it with them. They never discussed it with me. Because we just do not care about their lives etc. We care about those who exposed their lives while saving or backing up their comrades. From my block, three guys did not return. All three died heroically. One died in tortures. Now, tell me, why the f….k I am supposed to care about those who betrayed my three friends. Distancing, isolation, total silent rejection - this is what they deserve.

Just like we felt about Marine Lance Corporal who deserted and defected to the NVA IN Vietnam, or Corporal Aideed who left the USMC to go lead militia for his daddy, Somali Warlord Mohammed Farah Aideed, who fought Americans in Mogadishu., a task he performed in USMC Utility uniform & US load bearing gear.
Clearly the Russian had their helmet handed to them and sent packing for home. I would imagine the common soldier would have animosity for the Russian soldier deciding to turn traitor!
